title: Body Composition Monitoring Methods
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter has used various methods to monitor body composition over the years. He started with calipers, which is not the most objective standard and highly dependent on the skill of the individual doing the test. He then switched to hydrostatic testing, which turned out to be pretty inaccurate. Late 2011, Peter switched over to DEXA scanning, which is the gold standard. DEXA is very good at giving total body fat because it’s very accurate at measuring fat. Total body fat divided by total body weight is your body fat percentage.

title: Visceral Adipose Tissue (VAT)
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter emphasizes the importance of monitoring visceral adipose tissue (VAT), which is one of the compartments of fat that is outside of the subcutaneous stores. When we exceed our bathtub’s capacity to hold water and start to spill over, we begin to see VAT, which is highly inflammatory and effectively what Peter would call the fourth pillar of disease. It is important to avoid excess energy being stored in VAT and instead store it in subcutaneous pockets of fat.

title: Bone Mineral Density and Muscle Mass
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter also cares about a person’s bone mineral density (BMD) and muscle mass. He looks at a person’s Z scores and T scores to determine their BMD. The T-score is used to make the diagnosis of osteopenia or osteoporosis. Peter also looks at the two metrics of muscle mass: appendicular lean mass index (ALMI) and fat-free mass index (FFMI). These are two different methods to triangulate on the same sort of thing, which is basically how much muscle mass a person has for their height.

title: What is FFMI and ALMI and why do they matter?
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The FFMI takes the total fat-free mass in your body and divides that by your height in meter square. FFMI is a much bigger number than ALMI. Peter wants his patients to be north of the 75th percentile for ALMI and FFMI.

title: Importance of tracking data over time to see trends
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter has kept a spreadsheet for better part of 12 years where he logs his DEXA data. He keeps track of the various things happening in his life during those phases. There’s a bunch of variables, such as the passage of time, many changes in nutrition from very strict types of diets to fasting to completely unrestricted eating, and dramatic changes in the type of exercise he’s been doing. Not only does Peter track his DEXA data, but he does the same with his blood labs. He wants to see how does this number compare historically as opposed to looking at this number in isolation. Trends matter.

title: Peter's historical DEXA scan data
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: What you’re looking at is a relatively straightforward spreadsheet that simply records the data going back to May of 2011. The first DEXA scan Peter ever has was the same day that he did a hydrostatic dunk test. On that particular day, Peter completed a hydrostatic dunk test and it said he was 16% body fat which didn’t seem correct. He decided to go and pay the extra cost for a DEXA which showed is body fat to be 9.3% which was more in line with what he felt. As you can see, when looking at his DEXA on 5/3/11, his FFMI of 23.4 at that age, it’s above the 97th percentile. The important question here is: what was he doing at the time? Swimming a ton in the pool, lifting weights like crazy, and doing a bit of cycling as kind of cross-training. He was on a carb-restricted diet but not a ketogenic diet.

title: Body Composition
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter's body fat % went down to 7.5%. His FFMI went down a little bit to 23. Peter's goal would be to make sure that his FFMI is above about 19 putting him in the 75th percentile. When there is discordance between the ALMI and the FFMI, Peter prefers the ALMI because we actually have more data for ALMI. The ALMI truly tells you about what its name suggests, the appendicular lean mass index. It is the index of muscle mass in arms and legs. The FFMI is also true to its name, but it is somewhat confounded by the organs. So while Peter tracks that data—because it includes the musculature of the torso—you’ll sometimes see percentile discordance.

title: Exercise during Ketogenic Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: From 2011 to 2012, Peter transitioned into cycling. During this period, his exercise time is about the same (maybe slightly more), but now it’s on a bike. He was still lifting weights, but not quite as much. He was cycling 5 days a week. 2 days were really, really long days. 3 days were 90 minutes to 2 hours.

title: Getting off the Ketogenic Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter decided in the middle of 2014 to get off a ketogenic diet. While all his metrics of health were really good (e.g., blood markers were great, his performance was great, etc.). Note about performance on a keto diet: It takes while to adapt. It took Peter three months to just even get over the hump of feeling miserable when he exercised. It took him 18 months to get to the point where he couldn’t distinguish between being on and off carbohydrates. In the middle of 2014 is when he started to experiment with fasting.

title: Loss of Muscle during Ketogenic Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter says he was definitely not getting as much protein then as he is now, and that played a factor in the loss of muscle. In the 3+ years Peter was in ketosis, he was tracking his blood level of beta-hydroxybutyrate every single day. The mean level over those three years was like 1.73 millimole was the BHB level. The reality with keto is that it’s very difficult to get there if you’re consuming sufficient protein. If you’re hitting one gram of protein per pound of body weight, you are invariably kicking off some of that protein into gluconeogenesis, which is effectively raising glucose and kicking you out of ketosis. In fact, Peter has trouble staying in ketosis in 2011 and it was because his protein intake was too high. 80% of his calories came from fat back in those days.

title: Paradoxical OGTT Response
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: When carbohydrate restricted, there can be a paradoxical OGTT response where muscles become insulin resistant in response to the restriction of carbohydrates. This can result in muscles not being able to take up glucose, leading to higher blood glucose levels. This is an example of where we need to have a little bit of humility around this.

title: Metabolic Health Markers
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Body fat percentage is not as important as metabolic health markers. Important markers include lipids (both advanced and simple), triglycerides, fasting glucose, fasting insulin, insulin response, homocysteine, C-reactive protein, testosterone, uric acid, and liver enzymes.

title: Peter's Experience with Metabolic Health Markers
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: During his keto days, Peter's metabolic health markers were in good shape, including his triglycerides, fasting glucose, fasting insulin, insulin response, homocysteine, C-reactive protein, and liver enzymes. However, his uric acid levels were persistently elevated, which he later realized was due to beta hydroxybutyrate competing for the same transporter in the kidney that uric acid does. This can be a problem for metabolic health, but there is an explanation for it that is distinct from the normal reasons why elevated uric acid is a marker for bad metabolic health.

title: Total Body weight change
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Total Body weight only increased 0.8 pounds from 2014 to 2020. One might see this and say “Wow, this guy barely ages. What a beacon of health!” However, let’s take a closer look started with what changed over those years.

title: Changes to activity level
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter stopped cycling competitively — no more time trials, etc. He also had one or two years where he was being “completely aimless and meandering in my exercise” doing everything from bootcamps to running to doing my own workouts. But he never stopped exercising and his training volume only went down slightly. So what really fundamentally changed?

title: The role of fasting
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The answer is he started doing time-restricted feeding (TRF) and prolonged fasting. From 2014-2016, he was doing a ton of TRF such as OMADs (one meal a day). Then from 2017-2020 is when introduced fasting protocols. From 2017-2018 do a seven day of water-only fast once a quarter. By 2019, he changed to three day water-only fasts once per month. There was the belief that the net benefits of fasting made sense. So the motivation was “this is a really healthy thing to be doing and this is a great part of my longevity toolkit”.

title: Peter’s wake up call
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Overall, Peter wasn’t totally shocked that his BF% increased (he could tell he was a little softer). And to be clear, 16.1% BF for a 47 year old is not high (he was still in the 12th percentile aka leaner that 88% of people that age). His visceral adipose tissue (VAT) was 113 grams and that is VERY low (3rd percentile). Peter’s takeaways would be: Definitely have a higher body fat, but this is a healthy body fat. VAT is really low which is great. But he was a bit confused as to why his body fat was twice what it was before when I was seemingly not eating anything that much and not eating that often.

title: ALMI and FFMI from 2014 to 2020
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Now in 2020 his ALMI is 8.8 putting him in the 65th percentile. His ALMI in 2014 was 9.51 (85th percentile). FFMI in 2020 was 20.7 placing him at the 90th percentile.

title: Peter's Nutritional Approach
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter was fasting once a quarter for seven days or once a month for three days. He was restricting junk food but not deliberately restricting macronutrients. Peter's three strategies for energy reduction were calorie restriction, dietary restriction, and time-restriction. He was doing lots of calorie restriction but was bracketing it to these windows (fasting).

title: Peter's Shift to Adding Muscle
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter's trainer, Beth Lewis, advised him to add muscle. Peter decided to shift all of his focus towards putting muscle back on. He stopped fasting altogether and protein consumption became the only macronutrient in consideration when it came to his nutrition. He added a day of lifting weights.

title: Changes in Peter's Lifting Routine
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter went from lifting three days a week, Monday, Wednesday, Friday; where each day was a whole body workout to going four days a week; Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Sunday; where two days upper body, two days lower body. He increased volume of lifting and pushed progressive overload even further.

title: Changes in Peter's Blood Biomarkers
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter dropped fasting and pivoted to focusing on protein intake. No appreciable change in biomarkers was observed. Free testosterone levels are pretty consistently in the 9 to 11 nanograms per deciliter or 90 to 110 picograms per milliliter. From a biomarker perspective, things are fine.

title: Changes in early 2022
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter added blood flow restriction (BFR) to his workouts and started eating more calories to gain lean muscle. He continued to focus on protein consumption and training. However, he had to prepare for shoulder surgery in March 2022, so he did prehab for it. Prior to surgery, he had another DEXA scan and his total body weight was 187 pounds. His lean mass increased by 8.5 lbs and his fat mass increased by about 2 lbs. His body fat % stayed about the same, but his VAT increased to the 10th percentile.

title: DEXA scan in late 2022
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter had shoulder surgery in March 2022 and his body weight dropped to 172 lbs. He was still active, but he couldn't carry heavy things. He regrets not getting a DEXA scan at that time. After surgery, he began an 'insane recovery of eating.' In the summer of 2022, he was under a lot of stress from writing his book, but he decided not to sacrifice exercise, sleep, or time with family. However, he relaxed his restrictions on eating.

title: Muscle Loss and Inactivity
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The amount of muscle loss in a short period of time is definitely a function of lean mass because a lot of that you’re losing is glycogen and water as well. The more lean mass you’re starting with, the more you can lose. And the more inactive you are at a baseline, the less of a delta there will be.

title: Peter's Temporary 'Zero Restriction' Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter made the decision to just enjoy this period of time and he could really sense the stress eating. In those moments of late-night stress he would walk down to the pantry and get himself a bowl of mini-wheats and 'inhale them'.

title: DEXA Scan Results in December 2022
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Nine months post-surgery and six months post weighing 172 pounds, Peter now weighed 196.3 lbs. Of all that 10 pounds that he gained since February, two of them were muscle. His VAT was unchanged (down slightly, but within the margin of error and still under the 10th percentile). Lean mass went up slightly. Fat mass went up a lot (from 27 to 34 lbs). Body fat increased from 14.4 to 17.4%. Total body fat as you can see based on age, Peter is now about at the 20th percentile. Visceral fat, about 500, is at the 10th percentile.

title: Body Composition Changes
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: ALMI is like 10.2 kilograms per meter squared is sort of between the 90th and 97th percentile. FFMI was about 23.3. In the case of discordance bt ALMI and FFMI, he generally refers to the ALMI. It was a pleasant surprise that his VAT stayed the same. Remember, this is all relative: Peter has patients who live at 25, 30% BF and they’d give anything to be at 17%.

title: Peter's recent blood work
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter's recent blood work showed that his triglycerides were about 45 and his fasting insulin was about 7. His testosterone remains normal at 11 nanograms per deciliter for free testosterone. His liver enzymes went up a little bit, but he had switched to a different statin (from Pravastatin to Crestor), so it’s hard to interpret if there’s anything else going on.

title: Peter's nutritional and training approach following his most recent DEXA scan
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter added blood flow restriction (BFR) to his training and it has been hugely helpful in gaining more muscle mass. He gained 15 pounds and all of it was muscle. Fat mass went from 27.6 down to 27 and lean mass went from 137.5 to 153. Body weight went from 172 to 187. Peter's plan going forward after his latest DEXA scan in December 2022 is to try something nutritionally for the next four months that he’s never done before. He is going to use the app called Carbon (Layne’s app) to track his macros and lose 10 lbs of fat.

title: Peter's use of Carbon app to track macros
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter is using the app called Carbon (Layne’s app) to track his macros and lose 10 lbs of fat. The app has Peter at 184 grams a day for his protein target and a total calorie goal of about 2700 to 2800 a day. He is paying attention to calories and protein only and enters his body weight every day. The app is making adjustments every week.

title: Peter's protein intake during CR
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter's protein intake is the same now doing CR compared to six months ago. He’s still trying to get 45 to 50 grams of protein four times a day.

title: DEXA is not enough
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The same is true for DEXA. If you only relied on DEXA for your metric of health, that would be insane because you would load yourself up with every possible megadose of anabolic steroids, growth hormone, diuretics.

title: Context is important
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: It sounds trite and obvious, but you have to look at this stuff in the broader context of everything you’re doing. How is your sleep? Your overall state of your nutrition? Your blood biomarkers? Your functional metrics look like your VO2 max, your Zone 2, etc.
